text:
Here’s an SEO conundrum puzzling over. I found some of the higher ranking high volume keywords in a post I’m refreshing using an ahrefs report (list on the right) so that we don’t omit them from the refresh.

Then to double check, I took the identical list of keywords and popped them into Keyword Explorer and got very different volumes. Does this make sense to anyone?

elements.text:
Here’s an SEO conundrum puzzling over. I found some of the higher ranking high volume keywords in a post I’m refreshing using an ahrefs report (list on the right) so that we don’t omit them from the refresh.

Then to double check, I took the identical list of keywords and popped them into Keyword Explorer and got very different volumes. Does this make sense to anyone?

text:
Did the first set of numbers on the right come from ahrefs first report? There have been discrepancies between the volume that ahrefs provide and what it is in reality. They are estimates after all. 

I’d encourage you to pop your high traffic articles into Google search console, see what they’re ranking for and how much traffic they bring in month to month. Cross reference that traffic with what the keyword explorer tells you for the same keywords. I’ll bet you see the same problem. 

That’s why your whole content strategy shouldn’t solely be based on what the volume/difficulty of keywords are.

text:
No the numbers on the right came from Keyword Explorer, the numbers on the left came from the Site Explorer list generated from analyzing article.

Yes, this is just one of the factors I’m considering for the refresh strategy. It’ll be interesting to see what GSC says

text:
I wouldn't consider them related. An impression is recorded when a link to your site is shown in the search results for a page or query.

Check out #5 on this blog from Ahefs. It might provide some insights on how to think about search volume <https://ahrefs.com/blog/keyword-traffic-estimation/>

attachments.title: Why you can't ALWAYS trust keyword search volume for traffic estimations
attachments.text: Do pages that target (and rank for) high-volume keywords get more traffic than those that don't? Not always. Here's why...
attachments.fallback: SEO Blog by Ahrefs: Why you can't ALWAYS trust keyword search volume for traffic estimations

text: yeah so it looks like if those keywords are getting way more impressions on GSC then that's proof that there's a discrepancy. The question now is what do you do with this info. You'll have to decide if you want to give those terms up in the refresh. I'd say keep them all if you can. Don't keyword stuff, obviously but why remove them if they're getting clicks and impressions?

text:
Thank you so much everyone for your thoughtful responses. I love the idea of repackaging it as a course, so smart.

More context for those who asked:
• Our webinars are super performers (high registration, great attendance, unheard of in-chat engagement during the webinar)
• We don’t have time this quarter to create a new webinar, and we have an old webinar that matches up with our current campaign almost perfectly, so there’s an impulse to find a way to repurpose or relaunch this webinar in a way that gets similar performance
• We lead-gate all of our past webinars, including this one, which is available on demand already
• The goal(s) are a bit scattered, in that I think there’s a hunger to want to get new leads out of this, but more realistically it’s to get new _qualified_ leads - folks who are raising their hand as interested in this topic / conversation who are likely already on our list
Again, thank you so much!

elements.text:
Thank you so much everyone for your thoughtful responses. I love the idea of repackaging it as a course, so smart.

More context for those who asked:
Our webinars are super performers (high registration, great attendance, unheard of in-chat engagement during the webinar)

We don’t have time this quarter to create a new webinar, and we have an old webinar that matches up with our current campaign almost perfectly, so there’s an impulse to find a way to repurpose or relaunch this webinar in a way that gets similar performance
We lead-gate all of our past webinars, including this one, which is available on demand already
The goal(s) are a bit scattered, in that I think there’s a hunger to want to get new leads out of this, but more realistically it’s to get new
qualified
leads - folks who are raising their hand as interested in this topic / conversation who are likely already on our list
Again, thank you so much!

text: You should see the keyword volume discrepancies in Moz. I can see a MSV of 300 in SEMRush and Moz will show me 38 for the same keyword.

text:
That’s helpful context! I’m definitely not against rebroadcasting high-performing webinars (there’s a term for this called “simulive”). If the speaker(s) were internal SMEs, however, I would recommend rebroadcasting the same content live rather than doing it simulive. Use the same deck, plan, etc. but make it live. Then you can replace the on-demand version available on your site with the updated version. If you don’t have access to the same speakers because they were customers or experts or influencers, then simulive is probably as good as it gets.

Here at PathFactory, we don’t do it A LOT but we do it enough that I feel confident about it. For example, our highest-performing webinar of the year is always in early January and it’s about overhauling your nurture programs. We keep the bones of the webinar the same, but update it a bit with new insights, examples, results, etc. to keep it fresh. And we’ve repurposed portions of it for other broadcasts as well.

We also do a rotating series of live demos that is exactly the same every time, but we only promote it to people who haven’t seen it yet.

And when we’ve recorded customer case study sessions for virtual events, we’ll either use the recording and broadcast as-is or invite the customer to re-do the same presentation live in a more relaxed setting.

I don’t think you need to reinvent the wheel. As long as your segmentation is sound, then it’s unlikely anyone will notice you’re running the same material again. Nobody is paying that much attention.

elements.text:
That’s helpful context! I’m definitely not against rebroadcasting high-performing webinars (there’s a term for this called “simulive”). If the speaker(s) were internal SMEs, however, I would recommend rebroadcasting the same content live rather than doing it simulive. Use the same deck, plan, etc. but make it live. Then you can replace the on-demand version available on your site with the updated version. If you don’t have access to the same speakers because they were customers or experts or influencers, then simulive is probably as good as it gets.

Here at PathFactory, we don’t do it A LOT but we do it enough that I feel confident about it. For example, our highest-performing webinar of the year is always in early January and it’s about overhauling your nurture programs. We keep the bones of the webinar the same, but update it a bit with new insights, examples, results, etc. to keep it fresh. And we’ve repurposed portions of it for other broadcasts as well.

We also do a rotating series of live demos that is exactly the same every time, but we only promote it to people who haven’t seen it yet.

And when we’ve recorded customer case study sessions for virtual events, we’ll either use the recording and broadcast as-is or invite the customer to re-do the same presentation live in a more relaxed setting.

I don’t think you need to reinvent the wheel. As long as your segmentation is sound, then it’s unlikely anyone will notice you’re running the same material again. Nobody is paying that much attention.

text:
<@UJHBBR59V> the problem may be "Which" volume. 
In ahrefs you can see "global volume" and "country specific volume" (like US search volume).
Are you sure you are checking "global volume" from both site explorer & keyword explorer?
Check it once.

text:
We use all the tools mentioned above for different things. Our general rule: take keyword search volume, regardless of tool, with a grain of salt.

That your lists seem to follow the same pattern of high-to-low search volume tells me enough about what to prioritize & include.
